MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Substitute Teacher Employment Regulations.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the ruling in respect of the employment of substitute teachers for permanent whole-time primary teachers; and whether the substitutes so employed must be qualified and trained national teachers even where short periods of substitute work is involved.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: Substitutes are required to be employed for: (1) teachers absent owing to illness, after the third day of absence; (2) teachers absent on maternity leave; (3) teachers attending approved courses or absent for certain other approved reasons; and (4) teachers absent on jury service.

Substitute teachers are required to be qualified under the rules for national schools. Where it is impossible to obtain a qualified substitute, which would invariably only arise for short term absences, the services of a person who though not qualified under the rules is otherwise deemed suitable may be accepted.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Proposed Telecommunications Regulatory Body.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications
Qst.Quest: if she proposes to set up a regulatory body for the telecommunications industry which would help release the potential of the market and bring it into line with European thinking and aspirations for the development of communications.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn) Máire Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn)
Speaker.P: At present regulatory functions in regard to telecommunications are carried out by my Department.

The Commission of the European Communities is currently pursuing a policy of gradual liberalisation of telecommunications markets and the measures adopted to date, along with the further proposals now being considered, will require much regulation by member states of their telecommunications markets.

In the light of these EC developments it may be that there is a need for the setting up of a body, separate from my Department, to regulate the telecommunications industry in Ireland. The cost of establishing and operating such a body would, judging by the experience of other countries, be an inhibiting factor but I am keeping the need for the setting up of such a body under review.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dublin Hospital Patient Awaiting Operation.

Qst.Quest: when a person (details supplied) in Dublin 12, who claims to be waiting for a year for surgery in the Beaumont Hospital, will be admitted for this serious operation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I do not consider it appropriate for me to comment on the clinical details of an individual patient. The decision with regard to when a patient would have his/her operation performed is a matter for the consultant concerned. I have been informed by Beaumont Hospital that the patient was placed on the waiting list in May 1991. However, I understand that the hospital is not yet in a position to give a precise admission date.

MainHeading.P: If the patient's condition has deteriorated, she should contact her general practitioner who would be in the best position to take up the matter with her consultant.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Galway Community Centre.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the plans he has for the establishment of a community educational and development centre for County Galway; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: The Brothers of Charity have identified a need for a day educational service for children (aged six and over) with severe mental handicap in the Galway city area. The service will benefit six to seven children and will be initiated through the redeployment of resources within those available to the Brothers of Charity. It is proposed to commence the service after Easter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Meath County Council Projects.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the number and names of projects which have been submitted to his Department by Meath County Council for, (a) water schemes, (b) sewage schemes, (c) local authority home building schemes, (d) special grants for road repairs and building, (e) provision of new fire stations and (f) provision of new libraries, and if he will further outline the total cost involved and the number of these projects which will be approved in 1992.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Smith) Michael Smith
Speaker.P: The information requested is as follows:
(a) Public Water Schemes: Kells-Oldcastle, Stage 2; East Meath Regional, Stage 5; Trim; Batterstown; Curragha (Borehole); Enfield (Borehole); Summerhill.
(b) Public Sewerage Schemes: Navan; Trim (Extension); Dunboyne-Clonee; Batterstown; Bohermeen; Oldcastle.

The Kells-Oldcastle water supply (stage 2), east Meath regional water supply (stage 5) and Navan sewerage (advance section) schemes are under construction. The allocations for public water and sewerage schemes for 1992 have not yet been notified. The total estimated cost of all these schemes is £17.2 million.

(c) Local authority home building schemes: there are no proposals for local authority housing schemes awaiting approval. The local authority housing construction allocations for 1992 are being notified to housing authorities; it will be a matter for these authorities to nominate the schemes they propose to commence in 1992 within their allocations.
(d) Special grants for road repairs and building: there are no requests for special road grants with my Department.
(e) Fire Stations: Kells (2 Bay). The council's estimate of the cost of the proposals, which is under examination, is £316, 516.
(f) Branch Libraries: Ashbourne, Dunshaughlin, Oldcastle and Laytown
The total cost of these proposals is £1.174 million, which includes the provision of buildings and bookstock.
